initial_requirements: I want a website that helps families publish and manage memorial information, share memories, and interact with others around important family events.
user_stories: As a user, I want to publish funeral arrangements on the website, so that information about services is available.
As a user, I want the website to support multimedia memories, so that I can include photos, videos, or other media with obituaries.
As a user, I want access to a mortuary list, so that I can view information related to mortuaries.
As a user, I want functionality for condolences, so that messages of sympathy can be shared.
As a user, I want to publish my own obituaries, so that I can create memorials for my loved ones.
As a user, I want to manage my own obituaries, so that I can edit or update them as needed.
As a user, I want to publish my own funeral arrangements, so that I can share service details for my loved ones.
As a user, I want to manage my own funeral arrangements, so that I can edit or update service information as needed.
As a user, I want to view others’ obituaries, so that I can read about and remember other individuals.
As a user, I want to leave messages on others’ obituaries, so that I can express condolences or share memories.
As a user, I want the outer layout of the website to use cornsilk, so that the overall page background follows the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want the UI blocks of the website to use peru, so that the interface elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of community interaction should users have on a memorial page (e.g., posting tributes/memories, commenting, reactions, private messaging), and do you want any moderation/approval before posts appear?
conversation.user: On a memorial page, people should be able to post tributes/condolences and share memories with photos, and others can leave supportive comments or simple reactions. I don’t need private messaging. I’d like posts to go live immediately by default, but page owners should be able to turn on approval and report/delete inappropriate content.

conversation.interviewer: What forms of communication should be supported between users or between users and the organization (e.g. private messaging, group chat, real-time chat, Q&A boards)?
conversation.user: I don’t need general social features like private messaging or group chat beyond what’s on the memorial pages. What I do want is a way for families to directly create and update memorial content (obituaries, funeral details, service updates) and optionally send notifications or emails to invited guests when things change. A simple contact form or support email for reaching the organization is enough on that side.

conversation.interviewer: Besides basic report and delete options for page owners, do you want any additional moderation or history controls on memorial content, such as the ability to hide instead of delete posts, restore deleted items, lock comments on a post, or block specific users from contributing to a page?
conversation.user: Yes, I’d like page owners to be able to hide posts (instead of only deleting), edit their own posts, and lock comments on sensitive posts if needed. Blocking specific users from contributing to a page would also be helpful if someone is being inappropriate. I don’t need a full version history or restore of deleted items—simple hide/delete and basic controls are enough.

conversation.interviewer: For each memorial page, what specific ownership and management capabilities should the primary family owner (and any co-admins) have—for example, renaming the page, transferring or sharing ownership, controlling who can post or edit core details, or removing/limiting other contributors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed ownership workflows beyond something simple. One main family owner (with maybe a couple of co-admins) should be able to edit the memorial details, control who can post or comment, and remove or limit contributors if needed, but I’m not worried about things like complex ownership transfers.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s content to be organized and navigated—for example, how memorial pages are grouped (by family, by individual, by event), what main sections the site should have (e.g., memorials, upcoming events, past events, resources), and how users move between related pages like an individual’s memorial, their events, and family-wide pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a complex site-wide navigation structure. As long as each person’s memorial page is easy to find/search and clearly shows sections like obituary, events/service info, photos/memories, and tributes, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What specific types of information and data fields do you want the system to store for each key entity—such as a person’s memorial (e.g., name, dates, relationships, obituary text), individual events (e.g., date/time, location, RSVP details), and user-contributed posts (e.g., text, photos, reaction counts)?
conversation.user: For each person’s memorial, I’d want full name, dates of birth and death, a main photo, obituary text, basic relationships (spouse/children/parents), and optionally a short biography or story section. For events, I need title, date/time, location (with map link), type of event (funeral, wake, memorial, etc.), any livestream/zoom link, and simple RSVP/attendance info. For posts, just the author, timestamp, text, attached photos or videos, and counts of reactions/comments are enough; maybe a simple tag like “tribute” or “memory” if that’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any tagging or grouping system (like tags for themes, folders by family, or categories such as “military service,” “childhood,” “wedding,” etc.) to organize memorials and posts, or should everything just be organized by individual memorial pages without extra categories?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a tagging or category system right now. I’m fine with everything just organized by the individual memorial page, maybe with the simple “tribute” vs “memory” label if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on interactive components (like buttons, links, and highlights) on the site—for example, particular colors to use or avoid, or a general tone such as muted, bright, or neutral?
conversation.user: I’d like the main accent color to be in the peru/burnt-orange family—warm, calm, and not too bright. Please avoid very harsh neon colors; a muted, earthy tone that feels respectful would be ideal.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for text and interactive elements—such as meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios, providing a high-contrast mode, or avoiding light text on dark backgrounds?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict accessibility specs like AA vs AAA. Just make sure it’s readable and not low-contrast—no light gray text on white or anything like that.

conversation.interviewer: For key UI components like buttons, cards, and navigation bars, do you want them to use mostly white/light neutrals with the burnt-orange just as an accent, or should those components themselves have a soft, colored background (and if so, what general color family or tone)?
conversation.user: I’d like most components to stay fairly light and neutral, with the burnt-orange mainly as an accent (buttons, links, highlights). A soft off-white or very pale neutral for cards on top of a cornsilk-style background would be nice, so it feels warm but still clean and easy to read.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI elements should use the same standardized styling across the entire site (for example, buttons, form fields, cards, headings, and link styles)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific there—just keep things consistent site-wide for the basics like buttons, form fields, cards, headings, and links so it feels cohesive.

Feature33: As a family member, I want to create and update memorial content (obituaries, funeral details, service updates) directly through the site so I can manage information without needing staff intervention.

Feature35: As a user, I want the system to store for each post the author, timestamp, text, attached photos or videos, and reaction/comment counts so content and engagement are tracked.

Feature37: As a visitor, I want to move easily between a person’s main memorial page and their associated events so I can see all related information in one place.

initial_requirements: I want a website that helps me search and lease domain names, keep track of the domains I’ve leased, and handle payments and account management in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to search for domain names, so that I can find domains available for leasing.
As a user, I want to lease domain names, so that I can temporarily use domains I select.
As a user, I want to renew leased domain names, so that I can extend the leasing period of my domains.
As a user, I want to transfer domain names, so that I can move domains between accounts or owners as needed.
As a user, I want to view domain information, so that I can understand the details of each domain.
As a user, I want to view my domain leasing records, so that I can track my past and current domain leases.
As a user, I want user management functionality to be available, so that user accounts and related information can be managed.
As a user, I want payment management functionality to be available, so that payments related to domain leasing can be managed.
As a user, I want the website layout background to use old lace, so that the visual background appearance matches that style.
As a user, I want component details to use rosy brown, so that the visual appearance of components matches that style.

conversation.interviewer: What search filters and advanced query options do you need when finding domain names (e.g., TLD, price range, length, keywords, availability, registrar, lease term), and should selected filters persist between searches?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about advanced query options right now—basic keyword search plus TLD and price range is enough. Filter persistence isn’t important to me.

conversation.interviewer: When a user decides to lease a domain, how do you want the ordering and access flow to work—for example, should they add domains to a cart and check out, lease one domain at a time with a quick “lease now” action, or manage multi-year/auto-renew options during the same flow?
conversation.user: I’d like both: a quick “lease now” for a single domain and a cart for leasing multiple domains at once. In the flow, I definitely want to set lease length, enable/disable auto-renew, and clearly see renewal dates before confirming. Any changes later (like turning off auto-renew or extending years) should be done explicitly from my account, not automatically.

conversation.interviewer: For each domain lease order, what specific lifecycle stages do you want to track (for example: draft in cart, pending payment, active/confirmed lease, expired, cancelled, refunded), and which of these should the user be able to trigger themselves versus happening automatically?
conversation.user: I’d like to track: in cart/draft, pending payment, active/confirmed, expiring soon, expired, cancelled, and refunded/failed. Users should be able to cancel before activation, turn auto-renew on/off, and extend the lease; payment status changes, activation after successful payment, and expirations should happen automatically (with notifications).

conversation.interviewer: What data fields do you need stored and shown for each leased domain (e.g., domain name, TLD, lease start/end dates, renewal date, auto-renew status, price/payment method, status, registrar/owner contact, DNS nameservers)?
conversation.user: For each leased domain I want to see: the full domain name/TLD, current status, lease start and end date, next renewal date, auto-renew on/off, price (and billing frequency), and last/next payment status. Also show payment method used and basic DNS/nameserver info; registrar/owner contact is nice but not critical.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like leased domains organized in your account—do you need custom folders/tags/labels (and if so, what kinds), or is a simple sortable/filterable list enough?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about folders/tags/labels right now. A simple list that I can sort and filter by status, renewal date, and domain name is enough.

conversation.interviewer: What core business entities do you want the system to model and how should they relate (e.g., User/Account, Domain, Lease, Order/Cart, Payment/Invoice, Renewal, DNS settings)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how the business entities are modeled under the hood—as long as I can search domains, lease them, manage renewals and payments, and see my domain details clearly, the internal structure is up to you.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color (or primary brand color) would you like the site to use for key UI elements like buttons, links, and active states?
conversation.user: Let’s keep it simple—maybe a clean, modern blue as the primary accent color for buttons and links. I’m fine with you picking the exact shade, as long as it has good contrast and feels professional.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA or AAA) for text and interactive elements?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific standard like AA vs AAA—just make sure the colors have good contrast and are easy to read and use.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond the blue accent for buttons and links, what base colors do you want for main UI components like card/panel backgrounds and the top navigation bar (e.g., mostly white/light neutrals, or a darker/colored chrome)?
conversation.user: I’d like a mostly light look: use an old lace color for the main page background and cards/panels, with a clean white for content areas where needed. For the top navigation bar, I’m fine with either white or a slightly darker neutral that still fits with the old lace background and blue accents.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific visual aspects do you want us to keep strictly consistent across all pages and views (for example, button shape and size, link styling, heading hierarchy, spacing between sections, or card layout), so the interface feels uniform everywhere?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on that level of detail—just make the interface feel consistent and polished overall. If you want specifics, consistent button style, link styling, and heading hierarchy are probably the most important to me.

initial_requirements: I want a website that presents my professional background and experience in a clear and accessible way.
user_stories: As a user, I want the website to display personal information, so that visitors can learn basic details about me.
As a user, I want the website to display my work experience, so that visitors can understand my professional background.
As a user, I want the website to display my skills, so that visitors can see what capabilities I have.

As a user, I want the website to display my projects, so that I can showcase personal projects I have worked on.
As a user, I want to be able to browse the CV on the website, so that I can navigate through the different sections of my profile.
As a user, I want to be able to view my work experience on the website, so that I can see detailed information about my job history.
As a user, I want to be able to understand my skills and education background from the website, so that visitors can clearly see my capabilities and qualifications.
As a user, I want the website to use a light pink background, so that the visual appearance matches the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the site’s pages and navigation to be structured—for example, which main pages or sections do you want in the menu, and how should visitors move between them?
conversation.user: I’m thinking a simple top menu with sections like: About Me, Experience, Skills, Education, Projects, and Contact. Each section should be its own page or a clear scroll section, with the menu always visible so visitors can jump between sections easily. A consistent layout and maybe a breadcrumb or clear headings on each page would help people know where they are.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want visitors to browse your content within sections like Experience and Projects—for example, as a chronological list, a filterable grid (by role/tech), or a set of categories/tabs?
conversation.user: For Experience, I’d like a chronological list (most recent first) with role, company, dates, and a few bullet highlights, maybe expandable for details. For Projects, a grid of cards with simple filters (like tech stack and type) would be great, and each card can open a detail page or modal.

conversation.interviewer: When someone clicks an item in your Experience list or a Project card, do you want it to open a dedicated detail page, an in-page modal/expandable section, or stay on the same page with expanded content?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about which pattern you use—detail page vs modal vs inline expand—as long as it’s quick, readable, and easy to get back to where you were.

conversation.interviewer: Besides the main top menu, do you envision any additional way for visitors to switch between different “views” of your content (for example, a secondary set of tabs or a sidebar to switch between variants like compact vs detailed views of Experience or Projects)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about extra view switchers like tabs or sidebars. If anything, a simple “compact vs detailed” toggle on Experience/Projects could be nice, but it’s not a must-have.

conversation.interviewer: Within sections like Experience, Skills, and Projects, how would you like the content to be grouped or categorized—do you prefer everything in a single linear list per section, or should there be clear subgroups (for example, by role type, tech stack, or seniority level) to help visitors scan and understand your background?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about heavy grouping or categories. A clean linear list for Experience is fine, and for Projects the tech/type filters already cover what I need; Skills can just be grouped loosely (e.g., Languages, Frameworks, Tools).

conversation.interviewer: Are there any parts of your background—such as detailed project documentation, client names, or contact details—that you want to restrict behind a login or otherwise limit access to, or should the entire site’s content be publicly visible?
conversation.user: I want everything to be publicly visible; I’m not worried about hiding client names or project details. The only thing I’d want protected is my actual email address (e.g., via a contact form or obfuscation), but the site content itself can be open.

conversation.interviewer: For each top-level menu item (About Me, Experience, Skills, Education, Projects, Contact), should it be a standalone page, a section on a single scrolling page, or a mix—and if a mix, which ones are pages vs scroll sections?
conversation.user: I don’t really care whether it’s separate pages or one scrolling page—either is fine. Just keep the top nav always visible and make it easy to jump around and get back to where you were.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want the site to present different content or navigation depending on the visitor type (e.g., recruiter vs potential client vs peer), or should everyone see the same structure and pages?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about tailoring the site by visitor type—everyone can see the same pages and navigation. Keeping it simple and consistent is fine.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color (for elements like buttons, links, and highlights) would you like the site to use, and do you have any secondary accent colors in mind?
conversation.user: I’d like the primary accent color to be medium violet red. For a secondary accent, something neutral like dark gray/charcoal is fine—I don’t have strong preferences beyond that.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility targets for color contrast and readability—such as meeting WCAG AA or AAA contrast ratios for text and interactive elements—or should I just aim for generally high contrast and easy-to-read combinations with your chosen colors?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict WCAG targets like AA vs AAA—just aim for generally high contrast and easy readability with the colors we picked.

conversation.interviewer: For key UI components like buttons, cards, panels, and the top navigation bar, what base colors (e.g., light vs dark, specific shades) would you like their backgrounds or fills to use, assuming they’ll be combined with your medium violet red accent?
conversation.user: I’m picturing a generally light look: maybe a very light pink or off-white background for the main page, white cards/panels with subtle shadows, and a slightly darker (but still light) bar for the top nav so it stands out. Buttons can use the medium violet red as the main fill with white text, and maybe a light gray or soft pink variant for secondary buttons.

conversation.interviewer: Across all pages and sections, which specific visual aspects (such as button styles, card layouts, heading styles, or spacing rules) do you want to be kept strictly consistent so the site feels uniform everywhere?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict design rules as long as it feels clean and consistent overall. If anything, keep the same heading sizes, card style (white with subtle shadow), and button style/colors across the site.

initial_requirements: I need a poll website for users to cast their votes.
user_stories: As a user, I want to browse different voting options on the website, so that I can choose which option to vote for.
As a user, I want to vote for a selected option, so that my choice is recorded in the poll.
As a user, I want to view the voting results, so that I can see the outcome of the poll.
As a user, I want the website background to be colored white, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the component styles to be navy, so that the visual appearance of components matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of actions should users and admins be able to perform on polls and votes (for example creating/editing/deleting polls, bulk closing polls, changing options, or editing/deleting votes), and are there any specific workflows or approval steps you want for these actions?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about complex admin workflows or approval steps. Just need basic actions: admins can create/edit/close polls and users can vote (and maybe change their vote until the poll closes).

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to vote anonymously, or must they log in (and if login is required, what methods—email/password, Google/Apple, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If it’s simpler, require a basic login (email/password) so we can prevent duplicate votes and let people change their vote before it closes.

conversation.interviewer: What core pages and navigation structure do you want (e.g., a landing page, a polls list/browse page, individual poll detail/vote page, results page, user account/login page, and an admin dashboard), and how should users move between them?
conversation.user: I’d like it simple: a landing page that shows popular or recent polls, a main polls list/browse page with filters/search, and an individual poll page where you can see details, options, and vote. After voting, you should see results on the same page or a results tab, plus basic login/signup pages and a lightweight admin dashboard to manage polls. Navigation can just be a top menu: Home, Browse Polls, maybe My Votes/Account, and Admin (for admins only).

conversation.interviewer: On the Browse Polls and landing pages, how would you like polls to be grouped and organized (for example by categories/topics, tags, “popular vs. recent” sections, or user-specific views like “my polls/my votes”)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about elaborate grouping. Just show Recent and Popular, plus a simple search and maybe a couple basic categories or tags if it’s easy. A “My Votes” view would be nice but not required.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the site should be publicly viewable without logging in (e.g., poll list, poll details, results), and which should require an authenticated account?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on that. Just pick something simple that makes sense—maybe let people at least see polls and results without logging in, but require login to actually vote or see their own history.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want polls categorized on the Browse page—should there be a fixed set of categories (and if so, what are they), or should admins add tags freely per poll?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about detailed categorization. Just keep it simple—maybe a few basic fixed categories like Tech, Entertainment, Sports, and Other, and we can skip fancy tagging for now.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the site’s accent and component colors (for things like buttons, links, and highlights)—for example, a particular primary color or an existing brand palette we should match, or should we just use a clean, high-contrast default like a blue-accent theme?
conversation.user: I don’t have a strong preference—feel free to go with a clean, high-contrast default, like a blue-accent theme. Just make sure it looks modern and is easy to read and use.

initial_requirements: I need a dashboard that allows me to input and view financial data across multiple companies, and supports financial comparison and reporting.
user_stories: As a user, I want to use a multi-company dashboard to manage and view financial data from multiple companies in one place.
As a user, I want the dashboard to allow me to input financial data for each company, so that I can manage financial information across multiple companies.
As a user, I want to view financial data for a specific company by specifying its name or identifier, so that I can review company-specific details.
As a user, I want the dashboard to present revenue data for each company, so that I can understand each company’s income level.
As a user, I want the dashboard to present expense data for each company, so that I can understand each company’s cost structure.
As a user, I want the dashboard to present profit data for each company, so that I can understand each company’s profitability.
As a user, I want the dashboard to provide consolidated reports and cross-company comparisons, so that I can analyze overall financial performance.
As a user, I want the dashboard to use mint cream as the background, so that the interface follows the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want all dashboard components to be styled with teal, so that the interface elements follow the specified component styling

conversation.interviewer: How do you expect users to enter and manage the financial data (e.g., manual form entry, bulk spreadsheet uploads, editing inline in tables, approval workflows), and are there any specific CRUD or bulk-update operations that are essential for you?
conversation.user: I’m not too concerned about the exact way data is entered or managed. As long as it’s reasonably easy to get the data in and keep it up to date, the specific CRUD or bulk-update details aren’t that important to me.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pages you want in the dashboard and how should users navigate between them (e.g., company list → company detail → comparison/report pages)?
conversation.user: Core pages: a Company directory/search page (enter name/ID), a Company detail page with the financials over time, and a Comparison/Reports page where you pick multiple companies. Navigation should be simple: search/select company → detail, with a persistent selector to add companies and jump to comparison/reports.

conversation.interviewer: How should users browse and discover which companies are available to select beyond direct search (for example, do you want any categorized lists, filters, or curated views like “recently viewed” or “top companies”)?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on browsing or discovery—basic search is enough for me. Little conveniences like recently viewed would be nice, but they’re not essential to my requirements.

conversation.interviewer: On the Comparison/Reports page, what specific financial metrics and breakdowns (e.g., revenue, EBITDA, margins by year/quarter/month) do you need to visualize and compare across companies?
conversation.user: Mainly revenue, EBITDA, net income, and a few key margins (gross margin, operating margin, EBITDA margin). I’d like to see them over time by year, and if possible by quarter; monthly is nice-to-have, not required. Basic breakdowns like total vs. per-share or by segment/product aren’t critical but would be a bonus if they’re easy to support.

conversation.interviewer: What time granularity controls do you need for the financial charts/tables—yearly only, year+quarter, or should users be able to switch to monthly as well?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the time granularity controls. Yearly plus quarterly is plenty for what I need, and monthly would just be a nice-to-have if it’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond basic viewing of the metrics over time, what kinds of data analysis do you want the dashboard to support (for example, aggregations like totals/averages, time‑series trend analysis, simple forecasting, or automated anomaly detection)?
conversation.user: I don’t really need advanced analysis like forecasting or anomaly detection. Simple things like seeing trends over time and maybe basic totals/averages are enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the accent and component colors in the dashboard (for example, a primary highlight color to use for buttons, active states, and key metrics), or should we choose a clean, accessible default palette for you?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on accent colors—feel free to use a clean, accessible default palette. The only real preference I have is that the main background should be a mint cream tone so the interface feels light and easy on the eyes.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the dashboard to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard (e.g., WCAG 2.1 AA) for text and UI elements against the mint-cream background?
conversation.user: I don’t have any specific accessibility standards in mind. As long as things are readable and the contrast feels comfortable against the mint-cream background, that’s good enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What base fill color should we use for key UI components like cards/panels and the navigation bar (e.g., pure white, a slightly darker mint tint, or light gray)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a slightly darker mint tint for the cards/panels and nav so it stays cohesive with the mint-cream background, with teal used for highlights/active states.

conversation.interviewer: Across all pages of the dashboard, which specific visual elements do you want us to strictly standardize (for example, consistent card styles, chart color schemes for each metric, and typography sizes for headings/body) so the interface feels uniform everywhere?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict standardization details like that. As long as the dashboard looks consistent and clean overall, I’m fine letting you decide those specifics.

initial_requirements: I need a solar dashboard that lets me view real-time solar system data and explore historical data trends.
user_stories: As a user, I want a solar dashboard that displays both real-time and historical solar data, so that I can monitor my solar system comprehensively.
As a user, I want the dashboard to provide a real-time data display, so that I can see up-to-date information about my solar system.
As a user, I want the dashboard to provide a historical data query function, so that I can look up past solar data.
As a user, I want to view real-time solar power generation data on the dashboard, so that I can know how much power is being produced.
As a user, I want to view real-time power consumption data on the dashboard, so that I can understand how much power is being used.
As a user, I want to view real-time battery percentage on the dashboard, so that I can see the current battery level.
As a user, I want to view trends through charts, so that I can understand how solar power generation, consumption, and battery status change over time.
As a user, I want the dashboard background color to be honeydew, so that the interface has the specified appearance.
As a user, I want the dashboard components to use dark olive green, so that the components have the specified appearance.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main pages you want in the solar dashboard, and how should users navigate between them (e.g., a left sidebar with “Real-time” and “History” sections, tabs, or top navigation)?
conversation.user: Navigation isn’t that important to me as long as it’s simple and obvious. I don’t really care if it’s a sidebar, tabs, or top nav, as long as I can easily switch between real-time and historical views.

conversation.interviewer: How should users filter and query the historical data (e.g., by date range and metric), and do you want those filter selections to persist when switching between the real-time and history views?
conversation.user: I’d like to filter history by date range, and also by things like metric (production, consumption, battery), maybe inverter or system if there are multiple. It’d be nice if my date range and metric choices stayed the same when I jump away and back to the history view, but they don’t need to affect the real-time view.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want an advanced query builder for historical data (e.g., combining multiple conditions and saving those queries for reuse), or are the basic date-range and metric filters enough?
conversation.user: Basic date-range and metric filters are enough for me. I don’t think I need an advanced query builder or saving complex queries.

conversation.interviewer: What time granularity do you want for the historical trends (e.g., 1‑minute, 15‑minute, hourly, daily), and should users be able to switch between granularities?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact time granularity, as long as the charts look sensible and load quickly. If it’s easy to offer a couple options like hourly vs daily, that’s fine but not a must-have for me.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the dashboard to model and group around (e.g., site/system, inverter, meter, battery, PV array, and their relationships)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model or entities as long as I can view production/consumption/battery in real time and filter history by metric and date range. If you need something, grouping by site/system and maybe inverter/battery is fine.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the real-time and historical views organized into sections on the page (e.g., one overview page with production/consumption/battery cards and charts, or separate sections/pages per metric)?
conversation.user: I’d prefer an overview-style page that shows production, consumption, and battery together—like a few key cards on top and one or two charts below. I don’t need separate pages per metric; just let me toggle which metrics show on the charts if possible.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like the dashboard to use (e.g., a specific hex value or a named color like teal or orange)?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about the accent color, but I’d like the overall background to be a light honeydew/greenish tint so it feels clean and easy on the eyes.

user_stories: As a user, I want to browse poetry on the website, so that I can view available poetry content.
As a user, I want to browse different types of poetry, so that I can explore poetry by type.
As a user, I want to search for specific poetry, so that I can quickly find particular poems I am interested in.
As a user, I want to post my own poetry, so that I can share my poetry content on the website.
As a user, I want to comment on others' poetry, so that I can share my thoughts and feedback on their poems.
As a user, I want the website layout to use light goldenrod, so that the overall appearance follows that color scheme.
As a user, I want buttons and cards on the website to use olive drab, so that these elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What kinds of community features do you want for readers and writers—such as comments on poems, likes/upvotes, direct messaging, discussion forums, or following/friend features—and are there any of these you definitely do or do not want?
conversation.user: I definitely want comments on poems (threaded would be nice) and a simple like/upvote. Following favorite writers would be great too. I don’t really need direct messaging right now, and I’m on the fence about big discussion forums—maybe later.

conversation.interviewer: Could you clarify whether you want to completely exclude direct user-to-user messaging and real-time chat in the first version, or should there be any limited form of direct communication (for example, contact-the-author or contact-admin messages)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the details of messaging right now—whatever’s simplest is fine. Just no big chat feature in the first version.

conversation.interviewer: What specific moderation and history controls do you want for poems and comments—for example, should users be able to report content/users, block other users, edit or delete their own posts, and should admins be able to hide/remove content and view moderation history?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed moderation/history controls right now. Basic report button and letting people edit/delete their own posts is enough; admin remove/hide is fine too.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want user-created groups/collections (e.g., “poetry circles”), and if so, what member-management controls should the group owner/admin have (approve/ban members, assign co-admins, set who can post)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about user-created groups/poetry circles in the first version. We can skip that for now and revisit later if the core reading/sharing features are solid.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like poems to be organized and browsed on the site—for example, do you prefer navigation mainly by high‑level categories (e.g., love, nature, haiku), by tags, by curated collections, or some specific structure you already have in mind?
conversation.user: I’d like a mix of a few high-level categories (love, nature, haiku, etc.) plus flexible user-added tags. Browsing should support category pages, tag pages, and basic search/filtering (e.g., newest, most liked, by author). Curated collections could come later, but I don’t need them in v1.

conversation.interviewer: For poems, profiles, and comments, which parts of the site do you want to be publicly visible to anyone (even without logging in), and which parts should be accessible only to logged-in users or otherwise restricted?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about locking things down right now. I’m fine with poems and author profiles being public for anyone to read, and require login for posting poems, commenting, and liking.

conversation.interviewer: What should the main navigation page hierarchy be in v1—for example, which top-level pages do you want (Home, Browse/Categories, Tags, Search, Submit Poem, Profile, etc.) and what key subpages should sit under each?
conversation.user: For v1, I’d like a simple top bar with: Home (feed or highlights), Browse/Categories, Tags, Search, Submit Poem, and My Profile. Under Browse/Categories you could have the main genres/themes, and under My Profile just basics like My Poems and Account Settings—that’s enough for now.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want different types of users (for example, casual visitors vs. logged-in writers) to see different page structures or dashboards, or should everyone use the same pages with only small contextual differences like extra buttons for logged-in users?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about different dashboards or layouts. Using the same pages for everyone with a few extra options/buttons for logged-in users is totally fine for v1.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color would you like for key UI components (e.g., buttons and links) across the site?
conversation.user: A light goldenrod accent would be perfect—something warm and subtle for buttons and links, not too bright. It should work well on a mostly light/neutral background.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast requirements for text and key UI elements (for example, meeting WCAG AA/AAA contrast ratios for body text and buttons), or should we just aim for generally good readability without targeting a formal standard?
conversation.user: I don’t have any strict accessibility standards in mind right now—just aim for good readability and reasonable contrast so it’s easy on the eyes. If it roughly follows common best practices, that’s enough for v1.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components like cards, panels, and the top navigation bar use (e.g., white, off‑white, light gray, etc.)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much about the exact base/background colors. Something clean like off-white or very light gray is fine, as long as it looks good with the light goldenrod accent.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific UI elements should we strictly standardize site-wide for a consistent look (e.g., button styles, link styles, form fields, cards, typography, spacing rules)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about strict site-wide standardization details right now. Just keep the basics consistent—buttons/links, form fields, and poem cards—so the site feels cohesive.

initial_requirements: I want a website that connects students with internship opportunities and helps employers find suitable interns.
user_stories: As a user, I want the system to provide an internship portal website that connects students with companies offering internship opportunities, so that both groups can interact for internship placements.
As a user, I want the system to provide a student panel, so that students have a dedicated area to access student-specific internship features.
As a user, I want the system to provide a company panel, so that companies have a dedicated area to access company-specific internship features.
As a user, I want the students to browse internships via the student panel, so that they can view available internship opportunities.
As a user, I want the students to apply for internships via the student panel, so that the students can submit applications for positions they are interested in.
As a user, I want the companies to post internship positions via the company panel, so that they can offer internship opportunities to students.
As a user, I want the website to be optimized for navigation, so that I can easily find and access the features and information I need.
As a user, I want the website background to use the color mint cream, so that the site has the specified background appearance.
As a user, I want all components on the website to use the color teal, so that the components have the specified color appearance.

conversation.interviewer: How should the internship search work—what filters should users be able to apply (e.g., location, role, duration, paid/unpaid, remote), and should those filter selections persist as they browse or return later?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact filter list or whether selections persist—just whatever’s standard and easy to use is fine.

conversation.interviewer: What types of user accounts and permissions do you want—for example, should students and employers have separate roles with different capabilities, and should any parts of the site be accessible without logging in?
conversation.user: Yeah, I’d like separate accounts for students and employers with different capabilities—students can create profiles, apply, and track applications; employers can post internships, review applicants, and manage listings. I’d also like some parts public without login, like browsing internships and maybe basic company or student profile previews, but you’d need an account to apply or post.

conversation.interviewer: Should a user’s login session and account state stay synchronized across platforms (e.g., web and a future mobile app) so they can switch devices without re-authenticating?
conversation.user: I don’t really have a strong preference on that—whatever is standard and secure is fine, as long as logging in isn’t a hassle for users.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want any real identity verification for students or employers (such as ID document checks, school email verification, or company domain verification), and if so, in which specific situations should it be required (e.g., before posting internships, before applying, or only for flagged accounts)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about heavy identity verification like ID checks. A simple email verification is enough, and maybe verify employers via company email/domain if it’s easy to do.

conversation.interviewer: What are the main data elements you want to store and show for each internship listing (for example, fields like title, required skills, stipend/salary, location, duration, application deadline), and are there any special categories or groupings you definitely need (e.g., by industry, role type, or required major)?
conversation.user: Basic stuff like title, company, brief description, location/remote, duration, paid/unpaid and approximate pay, required skills, application deadline, and whether it’s full-time or part-time would be important. Grouping by industry and role type would be really useful, and if it’s easy, tagging things like preferred major or level (e.g., first-year, final-year) would be nice to have too.

conversation.interviewer: How do you want internships categorized and navigated—what are the exact top-level categories (e.g., Industry, Role Type) and should listings allow multiple tags within each category?
conversation.user: Top-level categories like Industry and Role Type are important, and maybe Location/Remote as another main way to browse. Listings should definitely allow multiple tags within each category (e.g., an internship can be both ‘Software’ and ‘Data’ under Role Type) so students can find relevant options more flexibly.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond students, employers, and internship listings, are there any other core entities you want the system to explicitly model in its data (for example, applications, messages between users, saved/bookmarked internships, or reviews/ratings), and how should they relate to students and employers?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the underlying data modeling details—just whatever’s standard to support things like applying, messaging, and saving internships if you think those features make sense.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the main accent color used on key components like buttons, links, and highlights (for example, a particular color family or brand color), or should we just use a standard, high-contrast color scheme?
conversation.user: Yeah, I’d like the main accent color to be teal across the site—especially for buttons, links, and highlights. Just make sure it’s high-contrast and readable, but teal should be the core color.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors (including the teal accents) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG 2.1 AA (or AAA) for normal text and UI components?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific named standard like WCAG AA vs AAA. Just make sure the teal and text contrast well and everything is easy to read.

conversation.interviewer: For components like cards, panels, and the main navigation bar, do you have preferred base/background colors (e.g., white vs light gray vs a very light teal), or should we just use a standard light neutral background and reserve teal mainly for accents like buttons and links?
conversation.user: I’d prefer a very light, mint-cream style background for the main areas so it feels fresh and clean, rather than plain white or gray. Teal should stay mainly as the accent for buttons, links, and highlights so it doesn’t get overwhelming.

conversation.interviewer: Across all pages and future platforms (like a possible mobile app), which specific visual aspects do you want us to keep strictly consistent—only the teal accent and mint-cream background, or also things like button shape, card style, and typography?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on that level of detail—just keep the overall look and feel consistent enough that it clearly feels like the same product. Teal accents and the mint-cream vibe are the main things I care about; the rest can follow standard best practices.

initial_requirements: I need a web application that lets me play chess online, where I can start or join games, make and undo moves, resign, choose different board themes and difficulty levels, and view my game history and statistics.
user_stories: As a user, I want to play a web-based chess game, so that I can play chess through my web browser.
As a user, I want to create new chess games, so that I can start playing chess online.
As a user, I want to join existing chess games, so that I can play in games that are already set up.
As a user, I want to move chess pieces, so that I can play the game turn by turn.
As a user, I want to undo moves, so that I can revert previous actions in the game.
As a user, I want to resign from a game, so that I can end a game I no longer wish to continue.
As a user, I want to click buttons to choose different board themes, so that I can change the visual appearance of the chessboard.
As a user, I want to have multiple predefined board themes (e.g., classic, dark, wood), so that I can customize the chessboard.
As a user, I want to click buttons to choose different difficulty levels, so that I can adjust how challenging the game is.
As a user, I want to have three difficulty levels (i.e., beginner, intermediate, advanced), so that I can select a level appropriate to my skill.
As a user, I want to view game history, so that I can see the record of moves in my games.
As a user, I want to view game statistics, so that I can see summarized information about my games.
As a user, I want to see the total number of games I have played, so that I can understand my overall activity level.
As a user, I want to see the number of games I have won, so that I can evaluate my success in the game.
As a user, I want to see the number of games I have lost, so that I can reflect on my weaknesses.
As a user, I want to see the number of drawn games, so that I can understand how often games end without a winner.
As a user, I want the application layout to use an Alice Blue background, so that the overall background color matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the application interface to use Steel Blue, so that the interface elements match the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: When starting a new game, what specific fields and settings should the “Create Game” flow include (e.g., time control, opponent type, rated/casual, color choice), and which of them should be required vs optional?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super detailed “Create Game” form. As long as I can quickly start a game or join one, and maybe optionally pick difficulty and a board theme, I’m good.

conversation.interviewer: Should users be able to play games anonymously, or must they create an account and log in before starting/joining a game?
conversation.user: I don’t really care either way. If you can let people play anonymously but offer accounts for saving history and stats, that’s fine.

conversation.interviewer: What main pages or sections do you want in the chess web app (for example: Home, Play, Game History, Statistics, Settings), and how should users move between them in the navigation?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on the structure. As long as there’s an easy way to get to playing a game, and somewhere to see my past games and stats plus tweak themes/difficulty, the exact pages and navigation don’t matter much to me.

conversation.interviewer: What core data entities do you need the app to store and relate (e.g., users/anonymous sessions, games, moves, game results, settings/themes, difficulty, history/stats), and what key fields must each include?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data entities/fields. As long as the app can track games, moves (including undo), results, and optionally tie history/stats and theme/difficulty preferences to an account, that’s enough.

conversation.interviewer: How long should completed game records (moves, results, and stats) be retained, and who should be able to view them (only the player, anyone with a link, or public)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about retention rules. Ideally my own games stay available in my account, and anonymous games can be temporary. Viewing can be private by default, with an optional shareable link if that’s easy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you want an audit trail for changes in the system (like modifications to user settings, difficulty presets, or corrections to game results), and if so, what specific details should each logged change include (for example, who made it, what changed, and when)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about an audit trail for settings or result corrections. Basic logging for debugging is fine, but I don’t need a user-visible change history.

conversation.interviewer: For interactive components like buttons, highlighted moves, and selected pieces, do you have any specific color preferences or requirements (for example, a particular accent color, high-contrast highlights, or colors to avoid)?
conversation.user: Yeah—please use Steel Blue as the primary accent color for buttons and interactive highlights. High-contrast highlights would be nice so moves/pieces are easy to see, but I don’t have strong “avoid” colors beyond anything that makes it hard to read.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility or contrast standards you want the app to meet (for example, WCAG AA or AAA for text and interactive elements), especially for users with low vision or color-vision deficiencies?
conversation.user: I don’t have any specific accessibility standards in mind. As long as it’s reasonably readable, with good contrast and clear highlights for moves and pieces, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar use (in addition to the Steel Blue accent)?
conversation.user: Let’s go with a light, clean look—something like an Alice Blue background for the main areas (cards, panels, page background), with the Steel Blue as the accent. The nav bar could either be a slightly darker shade of that light background or a muted Steel Blue, as long as text stays very readable.

conversation.interviewer: Which specific visual elements do you want to be strictly consistent across the entire app (for example, a single accent color, one button style, uniform card/panel style, and one font choice), and which elements—if any—are allowed to vary between pages or device types?
conversation.user: I don’t care too much about strict consistency rules. Just keep the Steel Blue accent and the light Alice Blue-style background consistent, plus readable text; layout can adapt between pages and for mobile vs desktop.

task_name: Custom Shirt E-Commerce Design and Ordering System
initial_requirements: I need an online shirt customization feature where I can customize a shirt, preview and confirm the design, and then place and pay for my order.
user_stories: As a user, I want to customize shirts in an e-commerce integration feature, so that I can personalize the shirts I purchase.
As a user, I want to input the shirt model, so that my selected model is used for my customized shirt.
As a user, I want to input the shirt fabric, so that my selected fabric is used for my customized shirt.
As a user, I want to input my measurements, so that the shirt is tailored to my size.
As a user, I want the system to generate a corresponding shirt design based on my input, so that I can see how my customized shirt will look.
As a user, I want to preview the generated shirt design, so that I can review it before confirming my order.
As a user, I want to confirm the generated shirt design, so that the final shirt matches my approved design.
As a user, I want the system to handle my orders, so that I can place and manage purchases for customized shirts.
As a user, I want the system to handle payments, so that I can pay for my customized shirt orders.
As a user, I want the global background color of the interface to be floral white, so that the visual appearance matches the specified color scheme.
As a user, I want all UI pieces to use dark goldenrod, so that the interface elements follow the specified color scheme.

conversation.interviewer: What specific editing tools and controls should the shirt designer include (e.g., add/upload graphics, add text, change colors, resize/rotate/position, layering), and how should the live preview behave while editing?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the specific editing tools; I just want it to be simple and easy to use. As long as I can clearly see what my final shirt will look like before I confirm and pay, that’s enough for me.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like customers to manage their orders after customizing a shirt—for example, should they be able to edit or cancel an order themselves for a certain time after placing it, reorder past designs, or is it enough that they can only place and pay for a new order each time?
conversation.user: I don’t really care much about post-order management. It’s fine if customers just place and pay for a new order each time.

conversation.interviewer: When customers are customizing and ordering a shirt, what specific information do you want them to enter in forms (e.g., size, color, quantity, shipping details), and are there any steps in that workflow you want to simplify or automate as much as possible?
conversation.user: I want customers to enter the shirt model, fabric choice, and their personal measurements, plus the basics like size (if applicable), color, quantity, and shipping + payment details. I’d like the flow to be as short as possible—auto-fill shipping info for returning customers and keep everything on a simple step-by-step checkout with a final preview/confirm screen.

conversation.interviewer: For the shirt customization and ordering system, what are the core data entities and fields you definitely want modeled in the database (for example, how would you structure things like shirt models, fabrics, measurements, and orders—any specific attributes or groupings they must have)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how the database is structured under the hood. As long as the system can support the options I mentioned (models, fabrics, measurements, order flow) and runs smoothly, the exact data entities and fields are up to you.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the customization experience organized into pages/steps—for example, a single-page designer with a step-by-step checkout, or separate sections for selecting model/fabric, entering measurements, designing/previewing, and then checkout?
conversation.user: I don’t really care how it’s split up into pages versus one page, as long as it feels simple and fast. A straightforward step-by-step flow with a clear final preview/confirm before payment is all I need.

conversation.interviewer: For the shirt customization and ordering site, which parts of the experience should be accessible to anyone (e.g., browsing models/fabrics, using the designer, viewing generic previews), and which actions or information should be restricted to logged‑in customers only (e.g., saving designs, viewing past orders, auto-filled details)?
conversation.user: I don’t really have strong requirements here. As long as anyone can customize and place an order easily, I’m fine with you deciding what needs login (like saving designs or auto-fill) versus what can stay open.

conversation.interviewer: What primary accent color should the UI components (buttons, links, highlights) use across the shirt customization and checkout flow?

As a user, I want to receive best practice and integration advice, so that I can use the system effectively and connect it with other tools.

conversation.interviewer: What controls or restrictions should admins have over messaging—for example, the ability to review and approve outbound messages, delete or edit sent messages, block certain senders or recipients, or limit who can send SMS/email to which lead segments?

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities you want the CRM to model and how should they relate (e.g., Leads, Contacts, Accounts/Companies, Deals/Opportunities, Activities/Tasks, Messages, Notes, Tags, Pipelines/Stages)?

conversation.interviewer: How do you want leads and related records to be categorized and grouped—e.g., tags/labels, custom lists/segments, folders, and/or multiple pipelines—and do you need rules for automatic tagging or grouping?

conversation.interviewer: What required system fields and table constraints do you want enforced across the CRM database (e.g., id format, created_at/updated_at, soft-delete flag, foreign key rules, and indexing standards)?

Feature19: As a user, I want files and media in a group to be presented in an easy-to-scan layout (list or list + small previews) so I can quickly find resources.

Feature20: As a user, I want the site to use a steel blue accent color for interactive elements (buttons, links, highlights) so the visual identity is consistent.

Feature21: As a user, I want the site to use an alice blue background on all pages, with cards and panels in white or very light neutrals, so the overall feel is clean and light.

Feature22: As a user, I want typography, button/input styles, and card/panel styling to be consistent across the site so the interface feels cohesive and predictable.

Feature23: As a user, I want the color scheme and contrast to follow standard web accessibility best practices so text and interactive elements are easy to read in different contexts.

task_name: Women’s Health Survey Information Management System
initial_requirements: I want a website that lets people submit health information and supports collecting and managing survey data.
user_stories: As a user, I want to access a health survey website specifically for women, so that I can fill out and submit my health information.
As a user, I want to fill out the relevant health survey on the website, so that I can provide my health information.
As a user, I want to submit my completed health survey information through the website, so that my data is sent to the system.
As a user, I want the system to provide data management functions, so that my submitted health information can be organized and maintained.
As a user, I want the system to provide permission management functions, so that access to my health information can be controlled.
As a user, I want the system to provide data review functions, so that my submitted health information can be examined and checked.
As a user, I want the system to provide reporting functions, so that information derived from my submitted data can be presented in reports.
As a user, I want the website to use whitesmoke as the default background, so that the visual appearance matches the specified style.
As a user, I want the website components to be styled in dark cyan, so that the component appearance matches the specified style.

conversation.interviewer: When someone is entering or managing health survey data on the site, what specific workflows and operations do you want to support (for example, step-by-step form completion, editing past entries, bulk uploads/updates, approvals, or other actions)?
conversation.user: I want a guided, multi-step survey form with save-and-resume, validation, and the ability for participants to edit their submission until it’s finalized. Admins should be able to review/approve, request corrections, and export data; bulk upload would be nice but not required at first.

conversation.interviewer: How should admins make and apply configuration/settings changes for the survey (e.g., changes take effect immediately, or they’re saved as a draft that requires review/approval before going live)?
conversation.user: I’d like survey changes to be saved as a draft first, with a clear “publish” step to push them live. If there are multiple admins, publishing should require an approval or at least be restricted to certain roles, and ideally changes shouldn’t affect in-progress submissions unless we choose to migrate them.

conversation.interviewer: For survey responses specifically, which operations do you want users and admins to be able to perform in the interface (e.g., create new responses, view details, update/edit, delete, duplicate, or apply any bulk actions to multiple responses at once)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about duplicating or bulk actions for responses right now. Users should be able to create, view, and edit their own response until they finalize it; admins should be able to view all responses, request corrections, approve/finalize, and export data. Deleting should probably be admin-only and ideally just an archive/soft delete.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core data entities (tables/records) you want the system to model for this health survey platform—for example Participant/User, Survey, SurveyVersion, Question, Response, Answer, AdminReview/Approval, and CorrectionRequest?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model details or table names—that’s something I’d expect the dev/architect to design as long as it supports the workflows we’ve talked about.

conversation.interviewer: What top-level sections/pages do you want in the site navigation (e.g., Participant portal, Admin dashboard, Surveys, Responses, Review/Approvals, Exports, Settings), and how should they be grouped?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact navigation structure as long as it’s easy to find things. At a minimum we need a participant area to take/edit surveys, and an admin area for reviewing/approving and exporting, plus basic settings.

conversation.interviewer: For health survey records and actions (like submissions, edits, approvals, correction requests, and deletions), what are your requirements around audit trails and retention—for example, how long should history be kept, who should be able to see detailed change history, and do you need “hard delete” or is soft delete/archiving sufficient?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed audit trail/retention rules right now. Soft delete/archiving is fine, and maybe keep basic timestamps (created/updated/finalized) and who approved, but we don’t need full change history unless it becomes a compliance requirement later.

conversation.interviewer: What accent/highlight color should the site use for primary actions (e.g., the main buttons and links)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a dark cyan as the primary accent color for main buttons and links.

conversation.interviewer: Do you need the site’s colors (including the dark cyan accent) to meet a specific accessibility contrast standard, such as WCAG 2.1 AA (or AAA) for text and interactive elements?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a specific WCAG level right now. Just make sure it’s generally accessible and readable with good contrast for buttons and text.

conversation.interviewer: What base/background color should key UI components like cards, panels, and the navigation bar use (e.g., white, light gray, dark, or another specific color)?
conversation.user: Let’s use a whitesmoke/light gray as the base background for cards and panels. For the navigation bar, a slightly darker gray (or dark cyan) would be fine as long as the text contrast stays readable.

conversation.interviewer: Which UI components should use the same standardized styling across the whole site (e.g., buttons, form inputs, cards, tables, alerts), rather than allowing page-specific variations?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about getting super specific here. Just keep the basics consistent across the site—buttons, form fields, cards/panels, tables, and alerts—so everything feels cohesive.

task_name: Bus and Railway Ticket Booking System
initial_requirements: I want a platform that helps me look up and book bus and train tickets, complete payments, and manage my trips and past bookings in one place.
user_stories: As a user, I want to search bus tickets, so that I can find suitable bus travel options.
As a user, I want to search railway tickets, so that I can find suitable train travel options.
As a user, I want to book bus tickets, so that I can reserve seats for my bus journeys.
As a user, I want to book railway tickets, so that I can reserve seats for my train journeys.
As a user, I want to view real-time seat availability, so that I can see which seats are currently available before booking.
As a user, I want to view real-time prices, so that I know the current cost of tickets before booking.
As a user, I want to make secure payments, so that my payment information is protected when I purchase tickets.
As a user, I want to receive booking confirmations via email, so that I have my ticket details in my email.
As a user, I want to receive booking confirmations via SMS, so that I have my ticket details on my mobile phone.
As a user, I want to register for an account, so that I can create a personal profile on the platform.
As a user, I want to log in to my account, so that I can securely access my personal information and bookings.
As a user, I want to view my booking history, so that I can see details of my past ticket purchases.
As a user, I want ticket printing options, so that I can print my tickets when needed.
As a user, I want the platform to have a responsive design that adapts to mobile devices, so that I can use it comfortably on my phone or tablet.
As a user, I want the platform to have a responsive design that adapts to desktop devices, so that I can use it comfortably on my computer.
As a user, I want all backgrounds configured with snow, so that the visual background appearance is consistently snowy across the platform.
As a user, I want all components configured with dim gray, so that the visual appearance of components is consistently dim gray across the platform.

conversation.interviewer: What are the key stages and actions you want supported in the booking lifecycle (e.g., search → reserve/hold → pay → ticket issued → change/cancel → refund) and any rules like time limits for holds or cutoffs for changes/cancellations?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about detailed hold windows or cutoff rules—as long as the app clearly shows whatever the operator’s policy is. For me the main flow is search, book/pay, get the ticket/QR code, and then be able to view, change or cancel if allowed, and see refund status.

conversation.interviewer: For each booking, do you want the system to explicitly track and label lifecycle states (for example: “in progress/draft”, “payment pending”, “confirmed”, “completed/trip taken”, “changed”, “cancelled”, “refunded”), and if so, which specific states and transitions between them are important for you?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about a super detailed state machine. I just want clear statuses like payment pending/failed, confirmed (ticket issued), changed/cancelled, and refunded (with progress) so I know where things stand.

conversation.interviewer: Beyond viewing status, changing, and cancelling, are there any other specific actions you want to be able to perform on a booking (for example, duplicate/rebook the same trip, download/print ticket, share trip details, or request support) directly from the booking details screen?
conversation.user: Yeah—I'd like to be able to download/print the ticket (PDF) from the booking screen, not just show the QR code. Rebook/duplicate the same trip and share trip details would also be handy.

conversation.interviewer: What are the core pieces of information you expect the system to store and show for each booking (for example, journey segments, passenger details, seat info, operator, fare type, payment details, and refund information), and how would you like these to be grouped or organized on screen?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about the exact data model or how everything’s grouped. Just show the essentials: route/segments with times, operator, passenger names, seat/coach if any, price, payment status/method, ticket/QR + PDF, and if cancelled, the refund amount and status.

conversation.interviewer: How would you like the app’s main sections and navigation to be structured—for example, what top-level tabs or menu items (such as Search, Upcoming Trips, Past Trips, Tickets, Account, etc.) should exist and how should related content be grouped under them?
conversation.user: I’m fine with something pretty standard: a Search/Book tab, an Upcoming Trips section, a Past Trips/History section, and an Account/Profile area. Tickets can just live inside each trip’s details rather than a separate tab. Under Account I’d expect my personal details, saved passengers, payment methods, and basic preferences.

conversation.interviewer: Which parts of the platform should be accessible without signing in (e.g., browsing routes/schedules/prices), and which should require an authenticated account (e.g., booking, payments, viewing tickets, managing trips and refunds)?
conversation.user: I don’t really care too much—as long as it’s convenient. Let people browse/search routes and prices without signing in, but require an account for booking/payment and for accessing tickets, trip management, and refunds.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific preferences for the app’s accent and component colors (for example, a primary brand color for buttons and highlights, or any accessibility/contrast requirements you want us to follow)?
conversation.user: I don’t have strong opinions on accent colors—just keep it clean and modern with good contrast so it’s easy to read. The only thing I do care about is a very light/snow-colored background across the app for consistency.

conversation.interviewer: Could you specify whether you prefer a particular accent color (or small palette of colors) for interactive highlights like buttons, links, and badges—for example, leaning more toward blues, greens, or another family—or should we just pick something that feels clean and modern as long as contrast is strong?
conversation.user: No strong preference on a specific brand color, but I’d like interactive highlights (buttons/links/badges) to consistently use a dim gray palette. As long as contrast is strong against the snow/light background, I’m happy.

conversation.interviewer: Do you have any specific accessibility requirements for color contrast and readability—such as meeting WCAG AA or AAA standards for text and interactive elements on the snow/light background?
conversation.user: I don’t really care about specific WCAG levels like AA vs AAA. Just make sure text and buttons are clearly readable with strong contrast on the snow background.
